name: Kepler-119
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-119 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-119 is a star with 0.7350000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.84 times its radius. It is located 2336.03 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-119 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-119 b

Kepler-119 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.42 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-119.

The mass of Kepler-119 b is 20.79 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-119 b is 3.6 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-119 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-119 c

Kepler-119 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.13 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-119.

The mass of Kepler-119 c is 0.79 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-119 c is 0.92 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-119 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-119, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
